Issues.Title: Screenreaders don't announce window title when application opens.
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

6.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

I haven't checked .net core, but it did the same in .net 5.0.

### Issue description

When an application loads, the form is in focus, but the active screen reader doesn't announce it's title when it should.
I have tried several workarounds, non of them make sense and actually should be done because this should work without any workarounds, but it didn't fix the issue. I have used nvda and windows10 narrator screen readers.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a standard windows forms app using the template without changing it.
2. Get a screen reader ([nvda](https://nvaccess.org) or windows10/11 narrator (ctrl+windows+enter) should do), launch it.
3. Build and launch.
4. The window opens and is in focus, but the screen reader doesn't announce it's title (the Form.Text property) when it pops up, but it should. To read the window title, you should alt+tab out then back again, as window title checking commands (Insert/capslock+t for nvda and capslock+t for narrator report wrong information).
I've made sure that the issue is reproducible not only on my pc, but on others as well.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Screenreaders don't announce window title when application opens." (#6896)

Issues.Title: Fixing TextBox accessible object leaks
Issues.Body:
Fixes #6885

## Proposed changes
- Use the `UiaDisconnectProvider` method cascade through the hierarchy of the classes to free objects held by accessibility tool
- Nullify needed objects

## Customer Impact
- TextBox memory will stop leaking

## Regression? 
- No

## Risk
- Minimal

## Screenshots

### Before
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/159485312-4729b9b1-19bd-425c-ace0-f44b484beb53.png)

### After
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/159485380-9b3d1f61-0460-40ea-b2a6-e3eff3695745.png)

### Future
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/159487064-78e2893a-ad41-4f2b-92d5-c1f4951b3dfa.png)

This fix isn't clearing all possible memory leaks. In the future nulling the `Owner` property at the `ControlAccessibleObject` class could be added:
1. This method should be added to the ControlAccessibleObject class:
```
                internal void ClearOwnerControl()
                {
                    this.Owner = null;
                }
```
2. Owner property shoud be changed from this
`public Control Owner { get; }`
to something like this
`public Control? Owner { get; private set; }`
3. Calling of the `ClearOwnerControl` should be added/uncommented at the `ClearObjects` method of the `TextBoxBaseAccessibleObject` class
4. These changes will produce different sorts of warnings: non-nullable member will became nullable, additinal checks for null should be added, etc. We discussed it with @vladimir-krestov and decided, that it's better to fix this leak after Vladimir will add new `TextPattern` functionality to the Core branch.

## Test methodology
- Manual testing (_using WinDbg, see the screenshots above_)
- CTI team

## Test environment(s)
- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.19043.1586]
- .NET 7.0.0-preview.3.22159.12

Issues.Title: TextBox accessible objects are leaking in memory
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

7.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

`TextBox` accessible objects are left in memory after the `TextBox` control instance was inspected with accessibility tool (like `Accessibility Insights` or `Inspect`) and the form with `TextBox` is closed, garbage is collected, but accessibility tool is still opened.

Report from WinDbg:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/159481920-cf26ae86-0a41-4d7c-a26f-5cb9d91de3e1.png)

**Expected behavior:**
Amount of the leaked objects should be minimized to the uncleanable static objects only.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a parent form with two buttons: one will be opening a child form with the `TextBox` control and the other will collect the garbage.
2. Press the second button to open the child form with `TextBox`.
3. Start the `Accessibility Insights` tools.
4. Run automated checks for the `TextBox` control using AI.
5. Close the child form.
6. Clear memory with the first button of the parent form.
7. DON'T close the AI tool.
8. Look for `TextBox` accessible objects left in memory (using `WinDbg`, or `dotMemory`, or another suitable tool).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "TextBox accessible objects are leaking in memory" (#6885)

Issues.Title: Allow using ApplicationConfiguration when the project is not runnable
Issues.Body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe

Hello,

today I came across the new feature of WinForms in .NET 6 - ApplicationConfiguration  which is great. It allows configuring the UI of the application directly in project settings.

I have a Windows Forms Application which uses backend with EF Core 6 etc. 
There are multiple layers. 
Due to this, the application should consume IServiceProvider which provides the services, yet, not depend on Data Access Layer.
Dependency from Windows Forms application to Data Access Layer is created when singleton services are configured in the Wndows Forms application.

Because of this, I created a "Launcher" project which initializes the IServiceProvider and then passes it to the Windows Forms application Main method as an argument.
There is an issue when the Windows Forms application is not runnable, the new .NET 6 ApplicationConfiguration object disappears.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64279914/159339936-e505993f-3d92-4ea4-af8c-08b86ec0ac8d.png)


I need to run the WindowsFormsApplication as a class library from the launcher but at the same time, preserve ApplicationConfiguration which allows configuring Windows Forms properties in project settings.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64279914/159340409-ae20cb4e-9050-4695-b5e8-f90353c52a15.png)


Is that possible and if not what would be a workaround?

Note: ApplicationContext is a custom class which needs to be used in UserControls because they don't allow constructor injection when they are wired into a Forms or other UserControls using the designer.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64279914/159340833-b14628d9-825e-4654-870f-8d7ba2d67bef.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64279914/159341079-544639bf-fb70-4008-bfd8-9f726dff98e0.png)



This is the proposed architecture and in this architecture, the Windows Forms GUI project is not directly executable because it depends on a IServiceProvider provided by the Launcher.

Diagram with dependencies below:
Note: the API layer contains interfaces for services and the Service layer implement these interfaces.
left: old architecture
right: new architecture which cannot be used 

![winforms launcher](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64279914/159340512-d73d0240-d934-46ec-adc1-4f2dedc94025.png)


Thank you

### Describe the solution you'd like and alternatives you've considered

ApplicationConfiguration  can be used in a WinForms project which is not runnable.

### Will this feature affect UI controls?

No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Allow using ApplicationConfiguration when the project is not runnable" (#6882)

Issues.Title: Closing an old WinForm affects ToolStrip ImageLists in a new Winform
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.Net Core 6.0.200




### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

For our WinForms Application, we have a number of global classes which are used between various forms. One of which is for ToolStrips where we store a global ImageList class, which is then loaded to each ToolStrip that is created on a form. This is to ensure only one ImageList needs to be created and icons are kept common between the ToolStrips we use throughout the application.

However, we have found that when changing forms (by calling .Show() on the new form and .Close() straight after on the old form), it appeared to set the ImageList properties to empty in the ToolStrips on the new form, meaning none of the images would show on the ToolStrip. After debugging and stepping through every part of the code that may have cause the property to set to null, I found that the .Close() call on the old form was setting the ImageList on the ToolStrips to empty.

The forms and the code behind them were not changed at all when converting the project from .Net Framework to .Net Core. This only seems to affect the .Net Core project.

I've created an example project with 2 identical forms, both having a tool strip with a single item and a button to open another form. The button image shows on Form1, and on Form2 when you open that, however the next time you click the button to switch forms, the image is no longer there.

[ImageListExample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/8317886/ImageListExample.zip)

Not sure why this works on Framework and not Core. I have been able to get around the issue by loading the global ImageList each time rather than setting it at program start, but it's an extra processing step which could potentially lead to (albeit minor) slowdowns.

### Steps to reproduce

- Run the attached project
- Click button1 on Form1, notice the toolstrip at the top of Form1 and Form2 have an image (just a black square)
- Click button1 on Form2, notice the toolstrip no longer has an image displaying
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Closing an old WinForm affects ToolStrip ImageLists in a new Winform " (#6881)

Issues.Title: Empty finalizers removed.
Issues.Body:
Fixes #6858 ## Proposed changes Remove unnecessary empty finalizers. - [ResXResourceReader](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/55e1755b579395e7e22fecf340905c79ccfa9b1a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Resources/ResXResourceReader.cs#L194) - [ResXResourceWriter](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/55e1755b579395e7e22fecf340905c79ccfa9b1a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Resources/ResXResourceWriter.cs#L549) - [ApplicationContext](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/55e1755b579395e7e22fecf340905c79ccfa9b1a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/ApplicationContext.cs#L91) - [DataGridViewBand](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/55e1755b579395e7e22fecf340905c79ccfa9b1a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/DataGridViewBand.cs#L817) - [DataGridViewCell](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/55e1755b579395e7e22fecf340905c79ccfa9b1a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/DataGridViewCell.cs#L1313) - [HtmlShim](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/55e1755b579395e7e22fecf340905c79ccfa9b1a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/HtmlShim.cs#L107) - [HtmlShimManager](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/55e1755b579395e7e22fecf340905c79ccfa9b1a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/HtmlShimManager.cs#L229) - [FeedbackRectangle](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/55e1755b579395e7e22fecf340905c79ccfa9b1a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/ToolStripPanel.FeedbackRectangle.cs#L55) ## Customer Impact GC will be more faster - overall improve performance (most impact on `DataGridView`). Simple `DataGridView` app, updating (replacing) `DataSource` every 1 sec with 10k unshared rows. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17767561/159126815-c4fee2d4-c41c-4fbe-870e-24f1d730d874.png) ~20sec measure time. Left before, right - after: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17767561/159127155-948b23ee-424e-401b-8f84-9027eb4d834c.png) Before: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17767561/159127229-97a488ca-e0f2-48fd-a2fb-db0ed7adafcd.png) After: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17767561/159127211-77b10655-14e6-40c1-b740-691fed26615e.png) ## Regression? - No ## Risk We have a _problem_ here: some of this finalizers are **public** api: - `~ResXResourceReader()` - `~ResXResourceWriter()` - `~ApplicationContext()` - `~DataGridViewCell()` - `~DataGridViewBand()` (absent in PublicAPI.Shipped.txt) Theoretically if some one had subclass this classes with real unmanaged resources, they may not implement their own finalizer but relay on fact that finalizer of base class will call `Dispose(false)`. And in this case it will be a breaking change So, in the end we can safety remove finalizers only in `HtmlShimManager`, `FeedbackRectangle`. `HtmlShim` is a question here - all his 3 child have `Marshal.FinalReleaseComObject` in Dispose, but only `HtmlElementShim` do it unconditionally in all cases: https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/2e9abddc2bab0c22430ae62d4a348ed6ffef329b/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/HtmlElement.HtmlElementShim.cs#L134-L143 https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/2e9abddc2bab0c22430ae62d4a348ed6ffef329b/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/HtmlDocument.HtmlDocumentShim.cs#L112-L124 https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/2e9abddc2bab0c22430ae62d4a348ed6ffef329b/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/HtmlWindow.HtmlWindowShim.cs#L103-L115
During investigation I found 2 [runtime](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime) types (**heavily** used in WinForms), that have same problem (in fact, there are many more): - `System.ComponentModel.Component` (public api) - `System.ComponentModel.Container` (public api) The most important question is what to do with the public api? As you can see, in case of `DataGridView`, **the benefit is very significant**. And if do such a braking change is not an option than we will need to rise https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/6859 priority...


P.S. Spent a few hours to run the application on the main branch - without effect Latest `dotnet-sdk-7.0.100-preview.3.22167.1-win-x64.exe` sdk is broken - it's need `7.0.0-preview.3.22158.1` to launch (no framework installed ) and with second available `dotnet-sdk-7.0.100-preview.2.22156.6-win-x64.exe`: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17767561/159127784-f2a01cfa-818d-4214-8831-fc3bbf5763a7.png) So, had to test on 6.0 branch... I think that [debug](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/debugging.md) doc mast be updated with clarification on this (debug apps with changes in main branch): - you need to install preview sdk (**exact** (must update dynamically?) version and where to get it) - set preview sdk in VS settings ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/6878)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Empty finalizers removed." (#6878)
